video.title: The 50 Most Popular Linux & Terminal Commands - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the 50 most popular Linux commands from Colt Steele. All these commands work on Linux, macOS, WSL, and anywhere you have a UNIX environment. 🐱

✏️ Colt Steele developed this course.

🔗 The Linux Command Handbook by Flavio Copes: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/the-linux-commands-handbook/

🔗 If you want to learn more about terminal commands and become a software engineer, check out the bootcamp Colt built with Springboard: https://www.springboard.com/courses/software-engineering-career-track-cvs1/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:37) Why use the command line?
⌨️ (0:06:56) The world of operating systems
⌨️ (0:10:56) What is Linux?
⌨️ (0:16:58) Shells and Bash
⌨️ (0:19:28) Setup For Linux Users
⌨️ (0:20:28) Setup For Mac Users
⌨️ (0:21:05) Setup For Windows (WSL)
⌨️ (0:29:43) Using The Terminal
⌨️ (0:31:12) whoami
⌨️ (0:32:34) man
⌨️ (0:33:40) clear
⌨️ (0:36:42) intro to options
⌨️ (0:39:05) pwd

⌨️ (1:53:52) piping

topLevelComment.author: Scott Sparling
topLevelComment.text: Just as a quick example of how much faster a terminal or cli is , one time after migrating drives, I had a ton of files duplicated with .copy appended to them, all throughout my folders. One single command (on windows, mind you) was del -s -r c:\users\sparl\*.copy.  it found all of them (hundreds) and would have taken days to do via a GUI. (I'm going from memory, the precise command may have been slightly diff, don't try without testing).

topLevelComment.author: Marcus West
topLevelComment.text: Excellent study. The graphical presentation is excellent. Thanks Colt. Is there one command to create files inside multiple directories? [touch breakfast lunch dinner]  [Weeks{1..52}/DaysOfWeek{1..7}]  I.E. how not to have to go into 364 files manually

replies.author: Meowmere
replies.text:
You can do it in two comamnds at least:
'$ mkdir -p Weeks{1..52}/DaysOfWeek{1..7}'
[If the needed directories do not already exist]
'$ touch Weeks{1..52}/DaysOfWeek{1..7}/{breakfast,lunch,dinner}'
[make sure the commas have no spaces after them]

There may be a way to do it in one command but those two commands will definitely work ^-^

topLevelComment.author: John Allsup
topLevelComment.text:
Something worth knowing about cp and mv is the -t option. If you specify e.g. mv -t aFolder file1 file2, then file1 and file2 are moved to the folder named aFolder. If aFolder does not exist, or is not a folder, this will print an error and stop. It is a useful way to avoid accidents when you want to move a single file to another folder, but mistype the target. For example consider
$ mkdir myFolder
$ mv myFile myFOlder
this will cause myFile to be renamed to myFOlder, possibly overwriting an existing file (unless you use the -n option). But
$ mv -t myFOlder myFile
will cause an error. This is especially useful in batch operations like for; do...done loops where you move one file per iteration.This is also a nice way to prevent cp from overwriting a file (alternatively the -n option prevents cp from overwriting).

topLevelComment.author: Gamer Steve
topLevelComment.text:
If you really want to understand the terminal, you have to look into it's history, going back to physical computer terminals, to teleprinters/teletypewriters (TTY) .   
A CTRL combination like ^Z or ^C actually sends a character code to the shell. These are called control characters (hence the CTRL key), as they don't represent graphical characters to be printed, but commands to control the device outputting the text. You can see them if you look at an ASCII table. For example ^G sends code 7, telling the receiver to ring a bell (a physical one originally). ^H (or the backspace key) moves the writing head back one character, which would let you fill in a space or print a character on top of another character, like O [Backspace] ^ would print Ô.
  
 ^C sends the "end of text" character. ^J sends the "line feed" character, which on typewriters would feed the next line to the writing head, without moving the carriage back to the beginning of the new line. To start writing the new line you'd then also need the "carriage return" control character ^M. This is why new lines are LFCR (line feed carriage return) on Windows. On Unix-like systems, only the line feed character is used.
You may be familiar with the C escape sequences for these control codes: \n (line feed) \r (carriage return) \0 (null) \t (horizontal tab)   
One thing I love is that the Delete code is 1111111 in binary. This is because it was designed for punched cards/tape, where it would overwrite any other character by punching a hole in every position, in contrast to \0 (null) - 0000000, which was supposed to be ignored and wouldn't do anything.

topLevelComment.author: APogeotropism
topLevelComment.text:
*Tip* for the “Permissions” segment:

The binary method that he explained at the end is actually the easiest way to go about changing permissions. He probably shouldn’t have called it the “binary method”… because, even I had a little bit of trouble understanding what he was talking about, at first… and I understand how to do it. Lmao

If he called it the “numerical method”, instead, it might have clicked a little bit sooner with those who are just starting out.

Just know that:
r=4
w=2
x=1

Therefore…

rwx=7
rw=6
rx=5
r=4
wx=3
w=2
x=1

so, if you wanted everybody to have rwx permission.

It would be “chmod 777 yourfile.txt”

Or, if you wanted to have all permissions but you only wanted your group to have read write and everybody else to only have read.

You would type “chmod 764 yourfile.txt”

This may seem a little confusing if you’re completely new to this… but, once you understand this method it will be a lot easier than trying to remember the u, g, o, a, method.

Because, as he pointed out in the video earlier… it can be confusing trying to remember that o stands for others, instead of owner.

And personally, I think it’s harder in general using the “chmod g+r” method…

Instead of having to learn how to use the + - = symbols… you can literally add and remove permissions with one simple command and remember it easier, by just using the numerical method.

I hope this makes sense and helps some people out.

However, this was a great video, Colt… You’re AMAZING for doing this!

2:44:20 I should point out that some Terminal emulators e.g. Dolphin in KDE (and I think also Nemo in e.g. Cinnamon) have a default history size of 500 or something. I found this out the annoying way; some commands had disappeared off the top of the list when I came to need them for reference.

Solution: Append "export HISTSIZE=10000" (without the quotes) to the end of your ~.bashrc .. pick a value which suits your needs, doesn't have to be 10000!

topLevelComment.author: William Steinhauser
topLevelComment.text:
Hey Colt: *awk* is a *very* useful command available on all Unix platforms, that should be included in this list. 
1) awk can be used like "grep", but smarter, with logic, calculations, and WAY more.
$  ls -l | awk '$5 > 9999'    # only list files larger than 9999 bytes. (size in 5th column)
2) awk is highly programmable, with internal logic, looping, and variables.
3) awk (like perl) is good for scanning logs with thousands of pages, to get summary
4) you can collect max/min, num+stat calculations, counts, etc from stdin.
5) most awk uses are short 1 to 4 liners; but long awk scripts can do complex analysis.
6) awk can efficiently work in 1-pass, where other tools may read big files many times.

Of course *sed* was not covered here either, and has been used for decades...

topLevelComment.author: BurningGlory
topLevelComment.text: Actually really helpfull for some programs I've been struggling with in freenas. Particularly I had an app that was supposed to be a media hosting service but when its set up it only gives the app permissions to write and execute and no one else, this was super frustrating when I went to make that folder (which the app used for a media pool) a SMB share so anyone on the network could dump files into it. Freenas (while a great program) offered no sensible way to do this through the GUI (which was heavily buggy and recently updated but marked as a stable release) but now I can just change the perms through the command line they offer. Thanks!

topLevelComment.author: Dustin
topLevelComment.text: WSL is actually in a VM and it has a integration wrapper so you can have a unified filesystem.  There is beta work on allowing the GUI applications to work, as well.  This all changed with WSL2.  The previous version was not a VM.

replies.author: Dustin
replies.text: @Jeff A It makes a virtual machine and then fully integrates with the local filesystem.  It is pretty slick.

replies.author: Jeff A
replies.text: So this is probably a dumb question but when using WSL does it make a separate partition to run in?

replies.author: Yiyu Zhou
replies.text: Exactly! WSL1 is similar to WINE on Linux, which is just an API translation layer running on top of the host system. WSL2 is a step back in terms of technology, but with a huge performance improvement.
